Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Development: Extensible, reproducible and documentation-driven microbiome data science.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Single-cellular organisms (microbes) represent a vast component of the diversity of life on Earth and perform an amazing array of biological functions. They rarely live or act alone and instead exist in complex communities composed of many interacting species that make up the microbiome. This award supports the development of the next generation of Quantitative Insights Into Microbial Ecology (QIIME, pronounced 'chime'), a free and open source software platform for analyzing microbiomes based on DNA sequencing data. Microbiome science is in a transformation from being descriptive and technically challenging, to becoming hypothesis-driven, actionable, and technically straight-forward, in part enabled by QIIME. We now know that the traditional approach for studying microbial communities, which relied on culturing microbes in the lab, is insufficient because we don't know the conditions required for the growth of most microbes. Recent advances link microbiomes to functional processes via 'culture independent' techniques, such as sequencing fragments of microbial genomes, and then using those fragments as 'molecular fingerprints' to profile the microbiome. The bottleneck in microbiome analysis is not DNA sequencing, but in interpreting the large quantities of sequence data generated. QIIME 2 will advance knowledge of microbiomes by helping users derive insight through interactive exploratory analysis capabilities, understand the underlying methods, and report their results in ways accessible to end users from outside of the field, including physicians, engineers and policymakers who urgently need access to conclusions drawn from studies of complex microbial ecosystems. Societal benefits range from global to personal (from understanding cycling of biologically essential nutrients, such as carbon and nitrogen in the environment to curing disease, including obesity and cancer). QIIME has been cited over 4,000 times and has active user and developer communities. Educational workshops on QIIME are taught approximately monthly in the USA and around the world.

At its core, QIIME 2 will provide a stable application programming interface (API) relying on existing community standards for documentation, coding style, and testing. It will have a novel 'documentation-driven' graphical user interface that will make QIIME accessible to users without requiring advanced computational skills. At the same time, it will help users improve their computational skills through exposure to the underlying bioinformatics methods. QIIME 2 will have fully integrated provenance tracking, which will simplify reporting and reproducibility of bioinformatics workflows. A first-class plugin system will decentralize development by allowing outside developers to add new methods to the QIIME 2 platform. The API will also support improved integration of QIIME as a component of other widely used systems, such as Illumina BaseSpace® and Qiita, and an automatically generated command line interface will be provided for power users. QIIME 2 will have a completely redeveloped parallel framework, which will support deployment on diverse high-performance computing resources, from locally owned and operated computer clusters to commercially available cloud computing platforms. All stages of QIIME 2 development will be driven by user community input through the QIIME Forum (currently over 2500 active users) and our public GitHub repository. Further details on this project are on the QIIME website (www.qiime.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vast majority of the diversity of life on Earth is made up of single-cellular organisms (referred to herein as microbes). Microbes perform an amazing array of biological functions, including essential ecosystem services upon which all multicellular life depends. Microbes rarely live or act alone, but rather exist in the wild in complex communities referred to as microbiomes, interacting with each other and their environments. These communities of microorganisms have far-reaching effects on our planet and our lives. For example, the composition of microbial communities in agricultural systems can impact pest resistance of crops and water retention on farms. The microbial communities that inhabit our bodies (the human microbiome) are now linked to many diseases, from obesity to diverse cancers.

In spite of their ubiquity and importance, our understanding of microbes and microbiomes is still in its infancy. As we crack their mysteries we will make major advances in applied and basic sciences. We’ll develop tools that will help us improve human health and medicine, support sustainable agriculture, create new technologies, and reduce our impact on the planet. We also stand to develop a better understanding of the origin of life on Earth, the processes of evolution and the origin of multicellular organisms, and rules governing the interaction of species in the environment. Microbiome science is at the center of a scientific revolution that can improve our lives, our children’s lives, and our world.

We now know that traditional approaches for studying microbes and microbiomes, such as culturing and microscopy, are insufficient because the majority of these organisms don’t grow in culture and their diversity far exceeds what we can visualize through a microscope. Recent advances linking the microbiome to processes ranging from global (e.g., carbon and nitrogen cycling) to personal (e.g., human disease, including cancer and asthma) have thus relied on genomics technologies, notably partial genome sequencing of all microbes in a microbiome. These new techniques for studying microbes and microbiomes result in massive datasets that require sophisticated software to analyze.

This grant funded the development of QIIME 2, a software platform designed in the Caporaso Lab at Northern Arizona University, that provides essential analytic and data visualization tools to support microbiome research. Over the course of the funding period the platform has become very widely used by the microbiome research community and is now being used in all sub-fields of microbiome science. QIIME 2 is accessible through different interfaces types, enabling access to its powerful functionality by biologists without advanced computational skills, but also through interfaces that are convenient for computer programmers and data scientists. QIIME 2 is fully open source and free for all use. You can find more details on the project at https://qiime2.org.

An essential component of this project was to provide training and technical support to QIIME 2 users. Toward this end we have developed a highly successful QIIME 2 workshop series (see https://workshops.qiime2.org) and to date have taught 36 official QIIME 2 workshops. We have trained thousands of students in these workshops. We additionally developed and maintain the QIIME 2 Forum (https://forum.qiime2.org), which serves as the hub of our global user community. We have thousands of active users on the forum, and we provide technical support and facilitate general discussion about microbiome research and bioinformatics for no charge. Our users are active in helping other users on the forum, and frequently share resources that they have created to help others. We have built a global community of software developers who contribute to QIIME 2. Illustrating this, the primary paper on QIIME 2 was published in Nature Biotechnology in July of 2019 (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41587-019-0209-9) with 112 co-authors from 77 institutions and ten countries, all of whom contributed to the design, development, documentation, or support of QIIME 2. As of October 2020, this paper has already been cited in over 1375 microbiome research studies.

We have successfully obtained additional grant support for the QIIME 2 project, ensuring its continued development. Dr. Caporaso is the PI of a five-year grant from the National Cancer Institute (1U24CA248454-01) and of a one-year grant from the Chan-Zuckerberg Initiative (2019-2073429) to support various aspects of QIIME 2 software and community development.
